abstract: The reasoning behind the decisions and the contentious way they divided camps within the agency illuminates how difficult choices are made inside the regulator.
snippet: The reasoning behind the decisions and the contentious way they divided camps within the agency illuminates how difficult choices are made inside the regulator.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s top regulator, sifting through the wreckage of the mortgage crisis, was weighing enforcement actions last year against several large financial companies.

headline.main: S.E.C. Tension as It Examined Mortgage Cases
headline.print_headline: S.E.C. Tension as It Examined Mortgage Cases

byline.original: By Peter Eavis and Ben Protess

abstract: Internal tension at the S.E.C. raises questions about whether the agency could have done even more after the crisis to hold Wall Street accountable. | What the jurors in the Michael S. Steinberg case thought. | How real people hurt by the Stratton Oakmont scandal fared. | Ronald O. Perelman’s donation to the NYU Langone Medical Center.
snippet: Internal tension at the S.E.C. raises questions about whether the agency could have done even more after the crisis to hold Wall Street accountable. | What the jurors in the Michael S. Steinberg case thought. | How real people hurt by the Stratton...
lead_paragraph: |  TENSION AT S.E.C. OVER MORTGAGE CASES After months of investigating the role of Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo and others in troubled mortgage securities — and even warning that enforcement actions were possible — the Securities and Exchange Commission shelved those cases and at least two others.

headline.main: S.E.C. Mired in Tensions Over Mortgage Cases

byline.original: By Chad Bray and Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: The California bank will start knocking more loudly on the door of the bulge-bracket Wall Street firms, asserts Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
snippet: The California bank will start knocking more loudly on the door of the bulge-bracket Wall Street firms, asserts Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo will start knocking more loudly on the bulge bracket’s door. The California lender is already one of the top 10 global investment banks by fees, according to data from Thomson Reuters. Much of that comes courtesy of middle-market clients. But if the bank run by John Stumpf starts going after bigger fish, it could put Wall Street’s bigwigs on the defensive.

headline.main: Wells Fargo Poised for Wall Street Run
